title: Delta Explained
badge_description: You understand the most important Greek - option directional exposure

screens.headline: Why do professionals obsess over this one number?
screens.text: Delta is the single most important Greek. It tells you EXACTLY how much your option moves when the stock moves $1. Master this and you'll trade like the pros.

screens.headline: Delta: Your Option's Speed
screens.text: Delta measures how much your option's price changes when the underlying stock moves $1. It ranges from 0 to 1.0 for calls (0 to -1.0 for puts). A delta of 0.50 means your option gains $0.50 for every $1 the stock rises.

screens.headline: Delta is Like Your Car's Speed
screens.text: Imagine delta is your speedometer. Delta 0.10 = 10 mph (slow, steady). Delta 0.50 = 50 mph (moderate). Delta 0.90 = 90 mph (blazing fast). Higher delta means your option moves FASTER with the stock.

reveal_sections.label: Delta 0.50 = ATM call (moves 50% as fast as stock)
Delta 0.90 = Deep ITM call (almost 1:1 with stock)

cards.definition: Shows how much your position moves with the stock
cards.example: Delta 0.50 = 50% as sensitive as owning stock

cards.definition: Sum of all your position deltas (total exposure)

screens.question: You own 1 call option with delta 0.60. The stock rises $3. How much does your option gain?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Delta 0.60 √ó $3 stock move √ó 100 shares = $180 gain. This is why delta matters - it predicts your profit.
screens.explanation_wrong: Remember: Delta √ó Stock Move √ó 100 shares. So 0.60 √ó $3 √ó 100 = $180 gain for the position.

screens.question: A put option has delta -0.40. What does the negative sign mean?
options: The option gains when stock goes DOWN
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Negative delta = inverse relationship. Puts gain value when stock falls, lose value when stock rises.
screens.explanation_wrong: Think inverse: Puts WANT the stock to fall. Negative delta means the option moves opposite to the stock.

screens.question: You're bullish on AAPL at $180. Which option gives you MORE exposure to a stock rally?
screens.explanation_correct: Smart! Higher delta = more exposure. The $175 call (delta 0.75) moves $0.75 per $1 stock gain. Lower strikes = higher delta = more aggressive.
screens.explanation_wrong: Higher delta = more directional exposure. The $175 call has 0.75 delta (highest here), so it benefits MOST from a rally.

screens.headline: Delta in Action: See It Move
screens.description: Adjust the stock price and watch how different deltas respond:

teaching_points: Notice: OTM option barely moves (low delta)
ATM option moves moderately (0.50 delta = half speed)
ITM option moves almost 1:1 with stock (high delta)

cards.back: How much your option price changes per $1 stock move. Delta 0.50 = $0.50 gain per $1 stock rise.
Delta approximates % chance of finishing ITM. Delta 0.70 ‚âà 70% probability of expiring in-the-money.
Calls: 0 to +1.0 (positive). Puts: 0 to -1.0 (negative). Negative = inverse relationship with stock.
Sum of all position deltas = total directional exposure. +500 delta = like owning 500 shares.
